on the meat of this talk is about browser rendering API so essentially
what it is is it's a tool that allows developers to programmatically control
and interact with headless browser instance and also creates automation flows for their application and products
right um how many of you here are familiar with POA that's good so if if you're trying
to do anything um around browser automation you possibly would have used this tool or possibly heard about it so
poeter is a nodejs library that provides an abstraction of the Chrome Dev tools
um to allow you instruments different tax so you can inspect the browser you can debug the browser you can you know
ask it to do specific things um poeta currently runs in headless mode by
default you can also set it up to you know run an actual Chrome or Chromium
browser the underlining thing here is that it uses under the hood uses the Chrome dep tools protocol which exposes
different apis like the browser the page that you can now use within um
poeter so how does this connect to Cloud flare workers um the brow browser
rendering API essentially is um running Puppeteer under the hood right
um remember the the the previous slide that I shared the Chrome def tools
protocol so the Chrome def tools protocol allows for tools to instrument inspect and debug chromium right so at
Cloud flare we the proper um repo and patched it to ensure that we can
connect to Cloud Fair workers why did we this why can't you just use poeter the reason being that poeter can only run in
a NOS environment whereas Cloud flare runs in the workers runtime environment
so it's impossible for you to use properti within workers so we are trying to enable developers building on workers
to be able to do similar things that they can do with Puppeteer within um Cloud flare workers so that's
essentially what the browser rendering API is um another interesting thing is
whatever you can do with potia so all the propeta apis you can also do with
the workers rendering API I'll show you examples so if you've used properer you
see that they are very um there there there are so many similarities between it's basically the same thing but it's
running on a different runtime and how did this come about um
rendering API was born out of internal need within the company right so we had a lot of developers that actually wanted
to do um Oru tools that involve involve browser automation but they were limited because of what I mentioned about it
proper running on NOS environment as opposed to running within workers so for example we have the cloud flare radar
URL scanner so Cloud flare Rader is currently a website that you know
collect TRS from the internet and they shipped a feature called the UR um Cloud
the Rader URS scanner where you can go in there putting a URL and then what
happens is the the the scanner will take it screenshot of your web page and you know check for Trends or metrics and
return that to you so the the process of going to take a screenshots that's actually um workers rendering API
happening there and underneath that that's actually prettier because you can um take a screenshots for example you
can run end to end test using um poppet here so this is an example of how we are
using the browser rendering API I'll show you other examples as we go on with the talk but how the it all work right
um the rendering API combines the power of cloud flare workers and something called remote browser isolation so part
of our zero trust offering we use um remote browser isolation under the hood and basically what remote browser
isolation is is it allows users to interact with a web browser in a
environment that is remote compared to like actually accessing the browser um
um directly from the client right so what we did is we wrapped potia Library
so potia is currently open source and the um Google Chrome team is working on
that so we um the properer library so that it works directly within
workers and what happens is when you make a request within your Cloud flare worker project and you try to create a
browser right or you try to send a request to for example navigate to a browser what happens is that there is a
web connection um that is being um created right so once the web connection is connected
and the connection is established our internal API which we have built um to
enable the communication between the Chrome um Dev tools protocol and Cloud
flare workers is then um connected and then going forward is is is possible for
you to for example do something like create a new um web page or navigate to
a browser to for example take a screenshot right so this is a essentially how it works under the hood
um within workers we have a Wrangler configuration file essentially what this
is is where you can configure specific things that you would like to have within your project for example if you
want to set up bindings if you want to add a compatibility flag and so on so
for browser rendering to work within your project you need to set up a browser binding and a browser binding
essentially would allow your worker to be authenticated to interact with a
dedicated Chromium browser instance and then secondly you need to also set up a compatibility flag that says nodejs
umore compat so with these two things set up within your project you can then start running um browser rendering
within your worker script also you would need to install the um Cloud flare Fork of poeta which
is an mpm package right so once you import that you can do things like
launch browser and for example create a new blank page or take a screenshot or
you know make a PDF there are so many different use cases for how you can use
um the workers browser rendering API within your project um like I mentioned the poeter
cloud flare package is on GitHub if you like to check it out and see what's um going on under the hood that's um
